intro: Leucopogon oppositifolius var. pubescens, commonly known as the hairy leucopogon, is a flowering plant native to parts of southeastern Australia. It belongs to the family Myrtaceae, which includes eucalyptus and tea trees. The plant is characterized by its opposite, hairy leaves that are often covered in fine pubescence. It produces small, clustered white or pink flowers that bloom in spring. This species is typically found in heathlands and dry sclerophyll forests, thriving in well-drained soils.
